question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
Consider the following system of linear equations

\begin{align*}
2x-y+2z&=a\\
x+3y-6z&=b\\
3x+2y-4z&=c,\end{align*}

where a,b, and c $\in\R$.

Give that x=y=z=1 is a particular solution to the system above,
determine the values of a, b, and c. Then find \emph{all} the solutions
in this case and express them in parametric form.
sols:
If we multiply the matrix A to the vector {[}1,1,1{]} we get

\begin{align*}\begin{bmatrix}
2  &  -1  &2\\
1  &  3  &  -6\\
3  &  2  &  -4
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
3\\
-2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

and therefore a=3, b=-2, and c=1. If we set those values permanently
then we know that {[}1,1,1{]} is a particular solution to the problem.
However, from
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 2 (b)}{part(b)}
we have that the solution to the homogeneous problem was

\begin{align*}\mathbf{x}_h=t
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

and therefore we can write that the general solution $\mathbf{x}$ is the
sum of the particular and homogeneous solution,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{x}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}+t
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}
hints: Multiply the matrix with the vector of \emph{x}, \emph{y}, \emph{z}.

Once we have a particular solution, how can we write the general
solution using our work from
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2012/Question 2 (b)}{part
(b)}?
